items.item_details:
Piedmont Hills Girls’ 4x400 Track Relay Team – State Finals First Place Winners
Ellisa Bryant
Timarya Baynard
Alexandra Diaz
Bianca Bryant
​
	 
	 
	 
Congratulations to Ellisa Bryant, Timarya Baynard, Alexandra Diaz and Bianca Bryant for earning a state championship in the 4x400 relays. I am so proud of them and their Coach Chioke Robinson for the dedication and commitment to making this relay team the best they could be.
	 
Below is the article from the Mercury News:
The Piedmont Hills 4x400 relay team knocked three seconds off its own Central Coast Section record at Friday's state meet trials, and then, incredibly, brought the 1-day-old record down another three seconds at Saturday's state meet finals.
The Pirates ran 3:41.14, the No. 2 mark in the nation, to win the state championship, obliterating the CCS record (3:47.81) they set at the Mt. SAC Relays, as well as the 3:44.47 they ran the day before at the trials.
The Pirates led throughout. Timarya Baynard ran a 55.4 leadoff leg, and Bianca Bryant, the fourth-place finisher in the 800, was clocked in 55.5 on the second leg. Sprinter Alex Diaz ran a 56.3 third leg, and Ellisa Bryant, the third-place finisher in the open 400, smoked a 53.8 anchor.
"I was proud of my team, getting us in good position,'' Ellisa Bryant said. "I didn't know how far behind they were, how close the next runner was. I was just thinking, 'Give it everything you've got.' I just wanted to win it for my coach and for Piedmont.''
After Friday's record-breaking run at the trials, Piedmont Hills coach Chioke Robinson said he thought the team could go faster, and if it did, would win a state title.
Robinson turned out to be absolutely on the money.
The Pirates became only the third team from Northern California in state meet history to win the girls 4x400 relay. Berkeley in 1974 and Skyline in 1994 were the previous winners.
"I just hope we did the CCS proud,'' Robinson said. "It felt so good to go blow to blow with Southern California.''
He made one change in the relay order, moving Diaz from fourth to third and Ellisa Bryant from third to anchor.
"I don't think it mattered what order we ran in,'' Robinson said. "But with (Ellisa) graduating, I decided, let her bring it home. She did that.''

items.item_details:
CIF State Track and Field Championships - Silver Medal Winner & CCS Champion
Miguel Vasquez – Andrew Hill High School
	 
	 
	Mercury News Article:
http://www.mercurynews.com/high-school-sports/ci_23372217/cif-boys-state-track-and-field-finals-andrew
	 
	 
	CIF boys state track and field finals: Andrew Hill's Miguel Vasquez takes second in 1,600
Andrew Hill's Miguel Vasquez was careful in setting goals for Saturday's state track and field championships at Buchanan High. After qualifying for the 1,600 at Friday's preliminaries, he said he knew it might be a stretch, but he would like to finish in the top three in the finals and break 4:10.
That turned out to be a modest wish.
Vasquez, unleashing the remarkable last-lap kick that has come to be his late-season trademark, went from seventh place at the start of the final lap to second at the finish line with a 58-second fourth lap, and was clocked in 4:08.44.
Vasquez has brought his best time in the 1,600 down 10 seconds the last two weeks, from 4:18.23 to 4:12.58 in winning the Central Coast Section championship and then down to Saturday's 4:08.44 in taking second at state. At that rate, give him a couple more races and he'll break the four-minute mile.
"In one race I decided to kick as fast as I could and I liked the way it felt,'' Vasquez said. "Since then I've been working on strengthening my pace.''
		 
Vasquez came back to take seventh in the 800 in 1:53.16, moving up from 12th to seventh on the final lap.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  8.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2012/2013-37 Schools and Domestic Violence Services
	 
Many of our students continue to experience or witness acts of domestic violence.  The Domestic Violence Advocacy Consortium of Santa Clara County (DVAC) is encouraging community members to help end domestic violence for the health and safety of our community and has designated October as Domestic Violence Awareness Month.
	 
According to the Center for Disease Control and Prevention, nearly one in four women in the country reports experiencing violence by a current or former spouse or boyfriend at some point in her life.  On average, more than three women a day are murdered by their husbands or boyfriends.  Although it affects people regardless of gender, age, sexual orientation, race or religion, women are much more likely than men to be victimized by a current or former intimate partner (U.S. Department of Justice).
	 
In 2011, there were 16 deaths related to domestic violence in the County, the largest number since 2003. From 2002-2010, there were 100 domestic violence related deaths causing incalculable trauma, pain and loss in our community. In fiscal year 2012, 23,700 individuals called local domestic violence crisis hotlines.  A total of 418 survivors and 317 children accessed emergency shelters.
	 
It is critical that all of our school staff are aware of the extent of the problem and know what resources are available to the victims of domestic violence.  Staff will need to be trained to recognize if the student is being exposed to domestic violence and teen dating violence so that they can then connect them to the appropriate services.  
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees Adopt Resolution #2012/13-37 Schools and Domestic Violence Services

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  8.04
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Donna Bertrand, C.P.M., Contracts Administration Coordinator
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Joint Use Agreement with West Coast Aquatics, Inc.
		 
East Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) is requesting authorization from the Board of Trustees to approve a Facilities Joint Use and Lease Agreement with West Coast Aquatics, Inc. (WEST) for the Agreement term of October 1, 2013 through and including September 30, 2016 for the non-exclusive use of the Swimming Pool Facilities at Independence and Evergreen Valley High Schools.  Based on the negotiated terms, the compensation WEST will pay to ESUHSD for the use of these Swimming Pool Facilities will be based on fair market rental for comparable facilities.
		 
ESUHSD operates swimming pools, diving pools, and related facilities including designated men’s and women’s heated showers and restroom facilities, locker rooms, and upper press box, and storage compartments at its comprehensive high schools including Independence High School and Evergreen Valley High School, (collectively, the “Swimming Pool Facilities”)
		 
WEST provides swimming lessons and organized swim sports activities on a fee basis to its participants and students, and serving the geographic region from Milpitas to Evergreen to Los Gatos, California.  WEST intends to use the Swimming Pool Facilities under the proposed agreement for organized and supervised swim and water polo practices; physical conditioning; swim instruction; parking for participants’ vehicles; meetings; and storage of equipment.  WEST also holds and sponsors swim meets, fundraisers, and competitions.  Those events will be administered under separate facility use agreements with the District.
		 
The parties may add additional Swimming Pool Facilities by a written addendum to this Lease Agreement and the primary use of the Swimming Pool Facilities shall remain with the ESUHSD.
		 
Pursuant to Education Code section 17529, prior to entering into a joint use lease or agreement, the Governing Board shall determine that the proposed joint occupancy and use of school district property or buildings will not do any of the following:
		 
(a) Interfere with the educational program or activities of any school or class conducted upon the real property or in any building.
(b) Unduly disrupt the residents in the surrounding neighborhood.
(c) Jeopardize the safety of the children of the school.
		 
Administration believes that the proposed agreement meets each of those criteria.
		 
		 
School/Department/Manager:
Evergreen Valley High School, Lauren Kelly
Independence High School, Grettel Castro-Stanley
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$90,000 estimated annual revenue
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees:
		 
1) Find that the proposed joint occupancy and use of school district property or buildings will not do any of the following:
		 
(a) Interfere with the educational program or activities of any school or class conducted upon the real property or in any building at Independence or Evergreen Valley High Schools.
(b) Unduly disrupt the residents in the neighborhoods surrounding Independence and Evergreen Valley High Schools.
(c) Jeopardize the safety of the children of independence and Evergreen Valley High Schools.
		 
2) Approve a Facilities Joint Use and Lease Agreement with West Coast Aquatics, Inc. for the of term of October 1, 2013 through and including September 30, 2016 for the non-exclusive use of the Swimming Pool Facilities at Independence and Evergreen Valley High Schools and, to authorize the Superintendent or designee to modify such Lease Agreement during the term as needed.

TO:

FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Dale Scott, Dale Scott and Company, and Charles F. Adams, Jones Hall
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action and Adoption of Resolution #2012/2013-35 Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of 2013 General Obligation Refunding Bonds in the Principal Amount Not to Exceed $110,000,000 for the Purpose of Refunding Outstanding General Obligation Bonds of the District
		 
The proposed Resolution authorizes the issuance and sale of 2013 General Obligation Refunding Bonds of the District in the maximum principal amount of $110 million, for the purpose of refunding two prior series of general obligation bonds which were authorized at the 2002 Bond election.  The two prior series of bonds, consisting of the Series D Bonds and the Series E Bonds, were issued in 2005 and are subject to redemption on August 1, 2013.  Proceeds of the Refunding Bonds will be used to provide funds to pay the redemption price of the prior bonds on the redemption date, and are expected to result in substantial debt service savings to the District’s tax payers.  The proposed Resolution authorizes the sale of the Refunding Bonds at either competitive public sale, or by negotiated sale, which provides the District with flexibility to determine which method of sale is most advantageous based on market conditions.  The proposed Resolution authorizes all actions required to close the bond issue.
		 
The Refunding Bonds are payable from ad valorem property taxes levied on taxpayers in the District.  Under California law, the Refunding Bonds can only be issued if there are debt service savings which result from the refunding, so the taxpayers are assured that property taxes will be reduced as a result of the refunding.
		 
FISCAL IMPACT: 
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Adoption of Resolution #2012/2013-35 Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of 2013 General Obligation Refunding Bonds in the Principal Amount Not to Exceed $110,000,000 for the Purpose of Refunding Outstanding General Obligation Bonds of the District.

Item:  8.06
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Dale Scott, Dale Scott and Company, and Charles F. Adams, Jones Hall
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2012/2013-36 Requesting Board of Supervisors of the County of Santa Clara to Establish Tax Rate for Bonds of the East Side Union High School District Which Are Expected to be Sold During Fiscal Year 2013-2014, and Authorizing Necessary Actions in Connection Therewith
		 
The purpose of the proposed Board Resolution is to formally request the County to include in the tax levy for fiscal year 2013-14 an additional property tax for the purpose of paying annual debt service coming due on a proposed issue of General Obligation Bonds under Measure I which was approved at the election held on November 6, 2012.  The proposed new bond issue will be in the estimated principal amount of $40 million.  Because the new bond issue will occur after the deadline for certifying the required tax rate to the County, the County requires the Board of Trustees of the District to formally request the additional property tax levy and provide for an estimate of the required tax to be supplied to the County.  The proposed Board Resolution is in a format which has been supplied by the County for this purpose.
		 
Adoption of the Board Resolution will not have any fiscal impact on the District.  When the General Obligation Bonds are issued under Measure I, they will be payable solely from ad valorem property taxes levied on District taxpayers.
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees Adopt Resolution #2012/2013-36 Requesting Board of Supervisors of the County of Santa Clara to Establish Tax Rate for Bonds of the East Side Union High School District Which Are Expected to be Sold During Fiscal Year 2013-2014, and Authorizing Necessary Actions in Connection Therewith.

SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:10 p.m. on the Provisions of the Charter School Petition of B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy to Consider the Level of Support for Each Petition by Teachers Employed by the District, Other Employees of the District, and Parents
BACKGROUND
	 
The B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy petition was submitted to the board on May 9, 2013. Pursuant to Education Code 47605 a public hearing is required within 30 days following the submission of a charter school petition to the board and a decision on authorization within 60 days unless an extension is agree upon by both parties. Both parties have agreed to an extension, where the Public Hearing will be held on June 11, 2013 and the decision on authorization will be made at the August 22, 2013 Board Meeting. 
	 
The purpose of the public hearing is for the Governing Board of the school district to consider the level of support for the petition by the teachers employed by the district, other employees of the district and parents.  
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To Be Determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
To Be Determined
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Hold public hearing to consider level of support for the petition submitted by B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  9.03
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2012/2013-33 Proposed Use of Tier III Categorical Program Funds (AB189) 
		 
Education Code 42605 grants districts flexibility in "Tier III" categorical programs and authorizes districts to use these funds for "any educational purpose, to the extent permitted by federal law."  For the 2008-09 fiscal year to the 2014-15 fiscal year, inclusive, local educational agencies that use the flexibility provision of this section shall be deemed to be in compliance with the program and funding requirements contained in statutory, regulatory, and provisional language.  
		 
As a condition the Governing Board is required, at a regularly scheduled open public hearing, to take testimony form the public, discuss, and approve or disapprove the proposed use of funding and to make explicit the purposes for which the funding amounts, and the proposed activities for which the funds are to be expended.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$19,714,451.00 projected
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Restricted/Unrestricted Funds
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees Adopt Resolution #2012/2013-33 the proposed use of  the Tier III Categorical Program funds as presented.

Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Director, Human Resources
					 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:20 p.m. Discussion and/or Action Regarding the Proposed Adoption of the Initial Proposal for the Successor Contract: From East Side Union High School District to the San Jose Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District presents the following initial proposal to the San Jose Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO for the 2013-2014 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547 the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
	 
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its certificated employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District.  Accordingly, the District initially proposes to continue the language of the present agreement for the 
2013-2014 school year except as modified in a manner consistent with the matters and issues described below.
	 
The District continues to experience severe financial constraints arising from a variety of factors.  The District views financial issues in the context of keeping the District solvent, maintaining the legally required reserves, and preserving the quality education for the students of the District.  Given the above, the District proposes the following areas for negotiations: Adjustments/reductions in total compensation which includes salary and benefits; and contract language amendments to Article 9000 – Leaves and absences.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board sunshine and accept any comment on the District’s initial proposal to the San Jose Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  12.01
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation on Calero Alternative High School Program
	 
The East Side Union High School District will be opening Calero High School in the fall of 2013. Calero is a small Alternative High School of Choice targeting students who have not found success at a large comprehensive high school. Calero High School will focus on graduating students prepared for college and careers in a global society. The educational program at Calero is centered on collaborative learning in both classroom and online environments to provide an innovative and tailored learning experience for students. Students will access all the courses required to both graduate and gain admission to universities. Students will attend an advisory period each day with their mentor teacher, where they will get personal support with 4 year planning, college exploration, and college applications, as well as education on cyber bullying, social media, and social issues.
	 
Calero's student population is small, serving 300 students, which allows for a personal and supportive learning structure.  Each student will have access to a personal computing device and learn to use technology as a 21st  century tool for learning, communicating, organizing, collaborating, and presenting.  Calero will serve students in grades 10 -12 and will open in the fall of 2013 with 10th and 11th graders only and grow to a full capacity in the fall of 2014.
	 
	 
Key components of Calero:
Small learning environment – 300 students
Focus on preparing students for college and careers
Online courses providing both enrichment and credit recovery
Staff mentor for all 3 years
Campus opens at 7:30 to provide students access to the digital café with classes starting at 8:30
Tutorial/Enrichment activities every day from 3:30 – 4:00
Each student will have a computing device
Access to a summer program
Tailored to the struggling student who did not find success in the traditional high school environment

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  13.01
	 
	 
TO:                              Board of Trustees
	 
FROM:                         Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
	 
PREPARED BY:            Cari Vaeth, Director, Human Resources
	 
SUBJECT:                    Discussion and/or Action to Approve Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators
	 
In July 1994, the Commission on Teacher Credentialing changed the process for emergency credentialing.  Prior to that time, districts were required to issue individual statements of need for each applicant.  The applicant, in turn, would take the declaration of need to the county office of education for the issuance of an emergency credential. This applies to the following credentials or authorizations: Emergency CLAD, BCLAD, Resource Specialist, Library Media, Clinical or Rehabilitative Permits.
	 
Now, the Commission issues a permit to an individual who qualifies for an emergency based on the district’s Declaration of Need.  This Declaration, approved by the local Board of Trustees, is submitted to the Commission once a year.  
	 
Emergency permits, although originally used primarily to staff partial assignments and special education, now help fill the fully credentialed teacher gap created by class size reduction and statewide teacher shortage.  Every attempt is being made to hire credentialed teachers before considering people on emergency permits.  
	 
Attached is the Commission on Teacher Credentialing form titled Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators.  Pursuant to direction from the county office of education’s credential’s office, the district is over estimating the number of permits it might require in order to cover any unanticipated needs that might occur during the course of the 2013-2014 school year.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
As per salary schedule
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
General, Special Education and Adult Education funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators.

Item:  14.01
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2012/2013-34 Pertaining to the Education Protection Account (EPA)
		 
The creation of the Education Protection Account (EPA) by Proposition 30 not only impacts cash flow patterns but also has an accountability component.  Proposition 30 provides that all K-14 local agencies have the sole authority to determine how the funds received from the EPA are spent, but with these provisions:  
		 
The spending plan must be approved by the governing board during a public meeting
EPA funds cannot be used for the salaries or benefits of administrators or any other administrative cost
Each year, the local agency must publish on its website an accounting of how much money was received from the EPA and how the funds were expended
		 
In addition, there will now be a requirement for the annual financial audit to included verification that the EPA funds were used as specified by Proposition 30.  If EPA fund are not expended in accordance with the requirements of Proposition 30, civil or criminal penalties could be incurred. 
		 
District’s Spending Plan:  All Education Account (EPA) funds received in 2012-13 and through 2018-19 will be used solely to support instruction and instructional-related services.
		 
As of the 2nd Interim Report, the District’s estimated revenue limit State aid is $66.3 million.  EPA will fund about 21.2% of the deficited revenue limit $139 million or $29.46 million.  EPA funds will be distributed in four (4) equal installments of $7.36 million September, December, March and June of each year. 
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the spending plan for EPA and Adopt Resolution #2012/2013-34 Pertaining to the Education Protection Account (EPA).

PREPARED BY:

SUBJECT:
Receive, Discussion and/or Action of Preliminary Budget as Recommended for Fiscal Year 2013-14 with May Revisions
		 
Attached for your review is a presentation of the 2013-14 Preliminary Budget as recommended. This is the second of three presentations of the budget to the Governing Board.  The preliminary budget is the result of a culmination of budget development activities between the sites, departments, and cabinet which provide a basis for the final budget.  The preliminary budget presentation is summarized first by providing an update on the District’s FYE 2012-13 budget, State budget update, and preliminary assumptions.  The FY 2012-13 budget is presented to provide year end projections for revenues, expenses, and ending fund balance. After reviewing the fiscal year end 2012-13 summary, major budget assumption updates for the 2013-14 budget will be discussed including May Revision School Services dartboard.   The impact and adjustments based on the Governor’s May Revisions have been announced and are reflected in this second preliminary budget update.  
The preliminary budget presentation summarizes the projected estimate for general fund revenues and expenses for the budget year 2013-14 and for the multi-year thru 2015-16 and incorporates all proposed savings, additions and adjustments to the district’s budget.  The presentation concludes with a summary of proposed actions and next steps in the budget process.  The final budget will be presented for budget adoption at the Governing Board’s June 27 meeting.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the Preliminary Budget as recommended for fiscal year 2013-14.

Item:  14.03
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services and Donna Bertrand, C.P.M., Contracts Administration Coordinator
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Joint Use Agreement with Escuela Popular for the Use of Classroom Facilities at James Lick High School
		 
East Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) is requesting authorization from the Board of Trustees to approve a Facilities Joint Use and Lease Agreement with Escuela Popular for the Agreement term of July 1, 2013 through and including June 30, 2014 with two (2) optional one (1) year renewals based on ESUHSD’s annual space review for the non-exclusive use of the Classroom Facilities at ESUHSD.  Escuela Popular will compensate ESUHSD for the use of these Classroom Facilities at rates that are determined and negotiated between the parties.
		 
Escuela Popular is a family learning center that serves Pre K-12 children and adults who are seeking a high school diploma. The growing need for English classes in east San Jose has created a need for more capacity for their high school program.  Escuela Popular will use the designated Classroom Facilities only for their High School program.  Special events shall be covered under separate agreements.
		 
The parties may add additional Classroom Facilities by a written addendum to this Lease Agreement and the primary use of the Classroom Facilities shall remain with the ESUHSD.
		 
Pursuant to Education Code section 17529, prior to entering into a joint use lease or agreement, the governing board shall determine that the proposed joint occupancy and use of school district property or buildings will not do any of the following:
		 
(a) Interfere with the educational program or activities of any school or class conducted upon the real property or in any building.
(b) Unduly disrupt the residents in the surrounding neighborhood.
(c) Jeopardize the safety of the children of the school.
		 
Administration believes that the proposed agreement meets each of those criteria.
		 
School/Department/Manager:
James Lick High School, Glenn VanderZee
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$42,000 estimated annual revenue
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
		 
1) Find that the proposed joint occupancy and use of school district property or buildings will not do any of the following:
Interfere with the educational program or activities of any school or class conducted upon the real property or in any building at James Lick High School.
Unduly disrupt the residents in the neighborhoods surrounding James Lick High School.
Jeopardize the safety of the children of James Lick High School.
2) Approve a Facilities Joint Use and Lease Agreement with Escuela Popular for the of term of July 1, 2013 through and including June 30, 2014 for the non-exclusive use of the Classroom Facilities at James Lick High School and, to delegate authority to the Superintendent or designee to exercise the two (2) optional one (1) year renewals and to modify such Lease Agreement during the term as needed.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  15.02
	  
TO:
Board of Trustees
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Kenneth Kerch, AIA, SGI Bond Program Manager
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Measure I Planning Process and Timeline, Authorize Allocation of $74.4M Measure I Funding, and Rescission of $20M Measure E Budget Augmentation from Fund 35, Measure G and State Matching Funds
	 
	 
On November 6, 2012, Santa Clara County voters approved Measure I authorizing the East Side Union High School District to issue general obligation bonds up to $120 million to upgrade computer/science labs; improve security/safety; repair, equip, and construct classrooms/facilities at Andrew Hill, Calero, Evergreen Valley, Foothill, Independence, James Lick, Mt. Pleasant, Oak Grove, Piedmont Hills, Santa Teresa, Silver Creek, Yerba Buena, W.C. Overfelt, and District adult, alternative, and charter schools; and acquire property for new schools.  
	 
Measure E Historical Perspective
When Measure E was allocated in 2009, an allocation plan was developed that provided the district with an approach to equitably prioritizing resources (February 19, 2009, Board Item 13.03).
	 
In that Measure E Equity Distribution process, the Board distributed monies to comprehensive high schools based on three weighted criteria:
Academic Performance Distribution:  the greatest share was allocated to the lowest academic performers (30%)
Bond Share Distribution:  the greatest share was allocated to campuses that received the least amounts of previous bond measure monies (30%)
Academic Master Plan Distribution:  funds were allocated to specific projects based on School Site Council priorities (20%)
Additionally, the Board distributed monies to:
Alternative Education Distribution (10%)
Technology Distribution (10%)
	 
By 2011, $274,585,000 of bonds had been issued; the remaining $74,415,000 could not be issued due to decreases in property values.  In consideration, the Board approved a Phase III Equity Allocation to mitigate disparities among sites using Fund 35 and Measure G funds (December 8, 2011, Board Item 14.01).  Phases I and II of Measure E projects are still in progress, and to date no work has commenced on Phase III projects.
	 
Measure I Allocation
In December 2012, the Board allocated $10,500,000 of Measure I Board discretionary funds to augment the Swimming Pool Upgrade Project (December 11, 2012, Board Item 16.03).  In April 2013, the Board allocated $1,000,000 of Measure I Board discretionary funds for the leasing and/or construction of the EduCare Silicon Valley facility (April 16, 2013, Board Item 8.02).
	 
In light of the Measure E history and recent authorizations for use of Measure I Board discretionary funds, the following Measure I allocation model is offered for Board consideration.  At all times Measure I funds will be used only for those purposes approved by the voters. 
	 
Measure I:  $120,000,000
Board discretionary allocation for Swimming Pools Modernization Project
$  10,500,000
Board discretionary allocation for EduCare Silicon Valley Early Learning Career Academy
$    1,000,000
Allocation for voter-approved Measure I uses that also restores previously Board-approved but unfulfilled Measure E allocations
$  74,415,000
Distribution to Sites
$  34,085,000
	 
	 
The above allocation is possible because many of the voter-approved Measure I projects also overlap with unfulfilled Measure E projects.  
	 
Under this proposed Measure I allocation model:
Measure I funds would be used for voter-approved Measure I projects while also simultaneously effectively restoring $74,415,000 of unfulfilled Measure E Board approved site allocations.  Thus, this proposed use of Measure I is not new site allocation; it is a restoration of Board-approved but unfulfilled allocation from February 2009 under Measure E in a way that is consistent with the Measure I bond.  Restoring these funds would facilitate fulfillment of the original intent of the Board approved site allocations but with Measure I funds now that such funding is available.  
$34,085,000 of Measure I funds would be allocated to school sites in the coming months, following a weighted criteria system similar to the one used in February 2009 for Measure E.  
$32,100,000 of Measure I funds used to restore “Land Acquisition” and “Board-Cabinet Contingency” at the District site would be used to fund and supplement infrastructure projects.  
Since Measure I funds would now be allocated towards $74,415,000 of unfulfilled Measure E projects, the “Phase III Equity Allocations” that were Board approved on December 8, 2011 (agenda item and Board action 14.01(3)) totaling $20,000,000 and funded by Fund 35 ($2M), Measure G ($2M), and State matching funds anticipated in early 2012 ($12M), and State matching funds expected in 2013 ($4M), which were a stopgap measure introduced as a result of the inability to issue the final series of Measure E bonds, can now be rescinded by this Board.  Per the December 2011 analysis and recommendation by staff to the Board, the augmentation was not anticipated to be necessary until mid-2013.  If that December 2011 Board action is now rescinded as recommended, then those funds would then be available for District discretionary initiatives, including payoff of loans that funded installation of solar photovoltaic systems. 
	 
Future Measure E proceeds from bond sales of $74,415,000 in approximately 2020, when property value increases allow for remaining Measure E bond issuances, would become Board discretionary funds (absent other Board action). 
	 
Measure I Planning Process
	 
An inclusive and collaborative planning process has already begun, to identify needs and develop recommendations for how to use Measure I allocations.  The process would build upon the planning work completed in 2008/2009 for Measure E, and implement the planning, recommendation and approval process put in place for Measure E, as follows:
Historical Analysis 
A review of past planning initiatives is in progress to ascertain projects that were identified, prioritized, and either implemented or deferred; those planning initiatives include the 2004 Facilities Master Plan, facilities condition and infrastructure studies, as well as previous Bond Measures A, the second A, G and E plans and outcomes.
Infrastructure Condition Studies
Historical infrastructure studies and analysis will be supplemented with additional survey work to identify a global infrastructure strategy for long term needs with associated cost projections.  The highest priority needs should be included on School Site Council Project and Priority Lists for consideration.
School Site Council Project and Priority Lists 
Historical analysis reports and updated infrastructure studies will be reviewed by District and Site administration, and School Site Councils.  School Site Councils will work with Facilities Planning staff to update their project and priority lists.  Project and priority lists will be informed by recommendations identified through the Strategic Planning Initiative.
	 
If School Site Councils require assistance in this matter, Facilities Planning staff may engage professional service providers (such as master planners) for assistance.
Superintendent’s Council Engagement
Site project and priority lists will be presented by Site Administration and Facilities Planning to Superintendent’s Council for review and recommendation.
Board of Trustees Approval
Once School Site Council and Superintendent’s Council are aligned on proposed project and priority lists, they will be presented to the Board of Trustees for approval.
	 
Timeline
The following timeline is proposed:
Historical analysis:  April - May 2013
Measure I Allocation Model development and approval:  April – June 2013
Infrastructure condition analysis:  May – October 2013
School Site Council project and priority lists:  May - October 2013
Superintendent’s Council review and recommendation of School Site Council project and priority lists:  November - December 2013
Board of Trustees approval of School Site project and priority lists:  January 2014
	 
FISCAL IMPACT: 
$108,500,000                                          
                                                                          
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure I general obligation bond funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees:
Authorize the allocation of $74,415,000 of Measure I funds for Measure I uses that would also  restore previously Board-approved Measure E site allocations in the same amount;
Rescind the Phase III Equity Allocation Budget Augmentation totaling $20,000,000 from Fund 35, Measure G and anticipated State Matching Funds which was approved by Board action on December 8, 2011, Agenda Item and Board action 14.01(3);
Authorize staff to proceed with the Measure I Planning Process and timeline delineated in this report; and
Authorize the allocation of $34,085,000 to District sites in accordance with and subject to the planning process in (3) above.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees: (1)	Authorize the allocation of $74,415,000 of Measure I funds for Measure I uses that would also restore previously Board-approved Measure E site allocations in the same amount; (2) Rescind the Phase III Equity Allocation Budget Augmentation totaling $20,000,000 from Fund 35, Measure G and anticipated State Matching Funds which was approved by Board action on December 8, 2011, Agenda Item and Board action 14.01(3); (3) Authorize staff to proceed with the Measure I Planning Process and timeline delineated in this report; and (4) Authorize the allocation of $34,085,000 to District sites in accordance with and subject to the planning process in (3) above.

SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action of Measure I Equity Distribution Methodolgy
	 
An equity distribution methodology is needed to fairly allocate Measure I funding in accordance with District priorities.  When Measure E was allocated in 2009, an allocation plan was developed that provided the district with an approach to equitably prioritizing resources (February 19, 2009, Board Item 13.03).
	 
In that Measure E Equity Distribution process, the Board distributed monies to comprehensive high schools based on three weighted criteria:
Academic Performance Distribution:  the greatest share was allocated to the lowest academic performers (30%)
Bond Share Distribution:  the greatest share was allocated to campuses that received the least amounts of previous bond measure monies (30%)
Academic Master Plan Distribution:  funds were allocated to specific projects based on School Site Council priorities (20%)
Additionally, the Board distributed monies to:
Alternative Education Distribution (10%)
Technology Distribution (10%)
For Measure I equity distribution, Administration proposes a weighted allocation of funds to comprehensive high schools in accordance with the following three categories:
API/SED/EL Distribution:  the greatest share is allocated to the schools with the lowest Academic Performance Index scores, the highest numbers of Socioeconomically Disadvantaged subgroup members, and the highest numbers of English Learner subgroup members.  For Measure E, each school’s API score was combined with performance gap and free and reduced lunch ratings to derive an academic performance ranking.  For Measure I, a similar combination of published data that is readily accessible and understood is equally weighted to derive the ranking.
SPED Distribution:  the greatest share is allocated to schools with the highest number of students qualifying for special education services.  For Measure E, the second category of Bond Share Distribution was derived to level the playing field of monies allocated from previous bond measures A, the second A, and G.  With the equity of capital funds that was created from that category in Measure E, it would be counterproductive now to continue to use that Bond Share Distribution criterion as it would punish those schools who recently realized funding equity.  For Measure I, this new special education category is proposed.  Special education has unique facilities needs with associated costs.  This new funding allocation category recognizes that schools with the greatest number of students qualifying for special education services also has the greatest need for higher cost facilities to support special education curriculum.
Permanent Modernized Capacity Distribution:  the greatest share is allocated to schools with the greatest need to eliminate portables and modernize original permanent spaces.  This goal of the 2004 Facilities Master Plan has not yet been fully realized, and remains an important aspect of achieving the best possible learning environment.  There are currently in excess of 260 owned and/or leased portable, temporary buildings at our school sites, many of which are approaching and/or exceeding their intended service life.  Funds expended on maintaining and repairing portable inventory are not as prudent an investment, due to the ultimately temporary nature of portable building construction.  This Measure I distribution category aligns funding with modernization of permanent facilities.
Additionally, Administration proposes to maintain an allocation of funds to:
Alternative Education Distribution
Technology Distribution
The Measure I Equity Distribution worksheet (Attachment A) shows category distribution percentages for each school site.  If the Board concurs with Administration’s proposed categories, proposed allocations for each category will be recommended at the next Board meeting.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not applicable
                                                                               
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure I general obligation bond funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the proposed Measure I distribution categories of API/SED/EL, SPED, and Permanent Modernized Capacity for comprehensive high schools, and Alternative Education and Technology major categories, and authorize staff to bring a proposed monetary distribution for the remaining $34,085,000 of Measure I funds at the next Board meeting on June 27th.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the proposed Measure I distribution categories of API/SED/EL, SPED, and Permanent Modernized Capacity for comprehensive high schools, and Alternative Education and Technology major categories, and authorize staff to bring a proposed monetary distribution for the remaining $34,085,000 of Measure I funds at the next Board meeting on June 27th.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  15.04
	  
TO:
Board of Trustees
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Kenneth Kerch, AIA, SGI Bond Program Manager
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Update the Facilities Master Plan for Independence High School
	 
The original 1969 Educational Specifications for Independence High School (IHS), by Davis MacConnell Ralston, contemplated a large site with four schools within the school, and the four “villas” that became the basis of the campus design was a manifestation of this educational specification.  In 2004, Perkins & Will developed an updated Facilities Master Plan (FMP) for IHS; the plan called for existing building modernizations for buildings that had not been modernized under previous bond programs.  The plan also called for construction of new restrooms at the L complex, a new Library/Media Center where portable buildings housing KIPP Charter School currently exist, and a new Public Library on the southern end of the campus between the Theater and the Art Complex.  To date, only the new Public Library has been constructed, and it is at the southwest corner of the campus.
	 
With the passage of time since the 2004 FMP, the subsequent modernization plans made in 2008-09 for the Measure E bond program, voter approval of Measure I in November 2012, together with academic delivery innovations that have been identified and are being further developed with the District’s Strategic Planning Initiative, an updated FMP is in order to ensure that facilities improvements are aligned with academic strategies.  
	 
The unique challenges and opportunities presented at Independence High School are as follows:
The original “villa” concept was for 4 separate schools, 4 separate administrations.  The site capacity of 4000 was to be separated into 1500-student villas, each individually administered.  Each villa housed principals, counselors, an attendance secretary, assembly halls, classrooms and support spaces, restrooms, and serving kitchens.  In reality, there were equity issues, factionalism, and operational inefficiencies.  Eventually, the concept of 4 separate schools went away; the villas now accommodate grade classes, not separate schools, and administration is centralized.  While improving operational efficiencies, there are challenges associated with serving such a large student body on an expansive campus.
The large student population of 3100 students provides the benefit of an expanded curriculum. Student survey results are very positive about the quality of instruction, and how students feel connected to the school. Parent survey results are also satisfactory.  However, there are operational challenges associated with that size population, including the ability to provide personalized attention, and the physical challenge of accommodating the student body in centralized locations for student support services or events.
External IHS and District pressures include:
2013 demographic study shows IHS area population growth in 7-10 years.  The study also shows an outflow trend of IHS students to charter schools.
Fiscal burden of outsourcing special education to the County Office of Education, and the missed opportunity of integrating and serving those students – where possible – at our high schools.
Facility issues at IHS:
The street address of 1776 Education Park Drive implies that the Education Park Drive side of the campus is the “front”.  That west end of campus is in reality less accessible than the N. Jackson Avenue east side of the campus, which nearly everyone treats as the “front” of the campus.  The west side of the campus presents a more difficult vehicular approach, and the approach through neighboring properties to the east side of campus is more direct.  Further, external organizations (Adult Education, Pegasus, KIPP, San Jose State University, County Office of Education) have a stronger physical presence on the west side than Independence High School itself.  
The lack of continuous fencing at IHS leaves the campus exposed and vulnerable from the east, west and south.  
The IHS campus is expansive, does not have intuitive pedestrian pathways or sightlines, or wayfinding signage to compensate.  It is easy for visitors and students to get lost.  
To date, the capital construction program has not produced any new buildings.  Modernization projects have produced updated "old feeling" buildings.
Desire for a student union / learning center for innovative academic delivery.
Facility opportunities that would be explored in an updated FMP include but are not limited to the following items  (refer to Attachment A campus map):
Develop a strong entrance experience on the eastern (N. Jackson Avenue) side of the campus.
Improve the outdoor experience with improved hardscape/landscape/wayfinding signage to facilitate navigation.
Relocate administration to the Jackson side of campus, for improved accessibility.  Develop a new/replacement building(s) on the Jackson side -- not for capacity, but for efficiency, functionality, and architecture that facilitates modern, innovative approaches to academic support delivery, including program spaces for administration, a student center, a student store, finance, a health clinic, and conference space for parent meetings.
Reduce the expansive size of IHS; physically reduce the footprint by creating separation from the entities on the west side of the campus.  The external entity “buffer zone” on the west side of the campus would improve security for IHS, and also further reinforce that Jackson is the “front” of the campus.
Modernize the former library building as a facility for the delivery of special services, with anticipated occupancy in academic year 2016-17 (due to occupancy by others in the prior academic year; see below).  Provide special education classrooms and a central learning lab, with program spaces for students with moderate to severe disabilities.  Efficiency would be realized due to centralization.  Yet due to adjacency, students would have enhanced opportunities for inclusion in the least restrictive environment, through participation with typical peers in classes on the IHS campus proper (e.g. art, music, etc.).
Introduce a dependent charter school to curtail the outflow of students to independent charter schools and simultaneously reduce the population at Independence by 400 to 600 students.  The dependent charter school would be a separate school, but by virtue of its adjacency the students could participate in certain aspects of IHS like sports, theater, ASBs.  A new facility at the southeast corner of the IHS site would allow for adjacency yet separation, as well as yet another opportunity to modernize the campus on the Jackson Avenue frontage. The modernized former public library building could house the freshman class in academic year 2015-16, while the new facility is under development.
The significant fire damage resulting from the March 3rd fire at Villa B presents an opportunity for reassessment in the larger context of facilities master planning. 
IHS School Site Council met on May 7, 2013 and gave approval to update their facilities master plan.  Superintendent’s Council discussed and reviewed the matter, and recommends an updated FMP for IHS.
	 
The proposed preliminary timeline for an updated IHS facilities master plan is as follows:
Master plan RFQ/P:  June 2013
Contract award:  June 2013
Master planning:  July – December 2013
Board approval:  January 2014                                                                            
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize administration to solicit proposals for facilities master planning at Independence High School, bring forth a recommendation for a facilities master planning contract award at the June 27th Board meeting, and proceed with the updated facilities master planning initiative per the delineated timeline.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize administration to solicit proposals for facilities master planning at Independence High School, bring forth a recommendation for a facilities master planning contract award at the June 27th Board meeting, and proceed with the updated facilities master planning initiative per the delineated timeline.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  16.23
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve Permanent Course Adoption for Digital Photo, Heritage Chinese Language and Culture I, Manufacturing Process 1 and Manufacturing Processes 2
	 
	 
The Instructional Policies Committee (IPC) has reviewed Digital Photo 2, ELD Literacy 4, Heritage Chinese Language and Culture I, Manufacturing Process 1 and Manufacturing Processes 2.  These courses was piloted during the 2012-2013 school year.  The course descriptions are included for your review.
	 
Digital Photo 2
Digital Photo 2 is a possible alternative option to Photo 2, as a second year course.  This class will build upon skills learned in Photo 1 with an emphasis in photographic digital technology.  It is a yearlong course that will stress the use of photography as a fine arts medium through the students' mastery of the "Elements of Art," as well as, the "Principles of Design.":  The class will address all five of the "California Visual Arts Standards,"which are as follows:  Artistic Perception, Creative Expression, Historical and cultural Context, Aesthetic Valuing and Connection and Relationships and Applications and will also meet the new common core standards as they are in the process.
	 
Heritage Chinese Language and Culture 1
This course is conducted entirely in Mandarin by the teacher and the students. The course work concentrates on refining listening, speaking, reading and writing skills; as well as introducing students to the culture of the Chinese speaking world.
	 
Manufacturing Process 1
Manufacturing Processes 1 is the second course in the four-year Manufacturing Magnet and Academy.  The students will learn additional woodworking and metal working skills and process.
	 
In this second year course, the curriculum addresses the Cabinet and Wood Products Pathway under the Building Trades and Construction Sector, the Machine and Forming Technology Pathway, and the Welding Technology Pathway under the  Manufacturing and Product Development Sector.  The students will be able to operate all of the machinery used in the previous course and additional machines such as the radial arm saw, jointer, router, metal lathe, and welding.  The students will learn to write a bill of material and operation sheets.  They will learn various woodworking joints such as butt, dado and groove, and how to safely square stock for accurate woodworking.  They will get to perform pocket milling, facing and turning on the metal lathe, and gas metal arc welding.  Measuring with a micrometer will also be discussed.  Students will be making a wide variety of woodworking and metalworking projects.  As the conclusion of the course, students will gain a broader scope of skills in woodworking and metalworking.
	 
Manufacturing Processes 2
Manufacturing Processes 2 is the third course in the four-year Manufacturing Magnet and Academy.  The students will learn more advanced woodworking and metalworking skills and processes than in the years previous.
	 
In this third year course, the curriculum addresses the Cabinet and Wood Products under the Building Trades and Construction Sector, the Machine and Forming Technology Pathway, and the Welding Technology Pathway under the Manufacturing and Product Development Sector.  The students will be able to operate all of the machinery used in the previous courses, and additional machines such as CNC router, CNC lathe.  The students will consistently measure to .001".  They will learn basic face frame cabinet making including making doors, and drawers, and CNC programming and operation.  The students can also choose to better their welding skills.  At this level in the Manufacturing Magnet and Academy, there are a lot of transferable skills learned between woodworking and metalworking.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the above courses.

SUBJECT:
Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students
	 
DESCRIPTION:  
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student's parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CAHSEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CAHSEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students' parents.
	 
The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in the Education Code 60851:
